When a small group of organisms (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it came (e.g. when they move over a mountain range or across a river, so that they can't easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
Over time the new population begins to adapt to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations look so different that they can no longer be assigned to the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an unavoidable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. One, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside of cultural or political influence, and two, that technology itself has "effects" on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network is not economically viable for a small number of cars. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the medical field to repair damaged bodies.

The use of ships for cargo transport is by far the most efficient way to transport large numbers of people and goods across the oceans.

Ancient cultures and tribes began to keep animals as pets to easily obtain their milk, fur, meat, and skin.

After his farewell address to Congress on July 4, a handwritten, signed by Congress President John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson, was sent a few blocks away to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as "Dunlap broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was given by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One was sent to George Washington on July 6, which he read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap broadsides that remain are the oldest surviving copies of the document. The original handwritten manuscript has not survived the ages.

Hershey and Chase used phages or viruses to insert their own DNA into a bacterium.
They took two experiments, in which they either marked the DNA of the phage with radioactive phosphorus or the protein in the phage with radioactive sulphur.

Traffic flow is the study of the movement of individual drivers and vehicles between two points and the interactions that take place between them.
Unfortunately, it's hard to study traffic flows, because you can't predict driver behavior with 100% certainty.
Fortunately, drivers tend to behave consistently; therefore, traffic flows have a certain constancy and can be roughly represented mathematically.
To better illustrate the traffic flow, the relationships between the three most important properties were defined: (1) Flow, (2) Density and (3) Speed.
These relationships help with the planning, design and operation of facilities at the roadside.

Today, dragonflies and mayflies are the only insects that cannot fold their wings.

Content theories focus on finding what moves or appeals to people.
These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires that are internalized as they mature.
These theories focus on what makes certain people want to do exactly the things they do, and what influences in their environment cause them to do certain things or not to do certain things.
Two popular content theories are Maslow's theory of the hierarchy of needs and Herzberg's two-factor theory.
In general, there are two behaviors that managers exhibit when they begin to lead their former colleagues. One end of the spectrum is the attempt to remain "one of the guys" (or one of the girls).
This type of manager has problems making unpopular decisions, implementing disciplinary measures, assessing performance, assigning responsibilities and taking on employees.
At the other end of the spectrum one becomes an unrecognisable individual who has to do everything differently than the team has done and takes everything for themselves.
In the end, the team leader is responsible for the success and failure of the team.
This behavior often leads to conflicts between the leaders and the rest of the team.
Virtual teams are managed to the same high standards as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
Virtual team members often function as a contact point for their immediate physical group.
They often have more autonomy than traditional team members, as their teams meet in different time zones that may not be considered by the local leadership.
The presence of a real "invisible team" (Larson and LaFasto 1989, p. 109) is also a unique component of a virtual team.
The "invisible team" is the leadership team, to whom each member reports. The invisible team sets the standards for each member.

AI is often associated with science fiction, but it's an important branch of computer science that deals with the behavior, learning and adaptation of machines.
Research in the field of AI includes the creation of machines to automate tasks that require intelligent behavior.
Examples of these skills are control, setting up strategies and time plans, the ability to answer customer questions and diagnoses, as well as handwriting, voice and face recognition.
Such things have become independent disciplines that focus on finding solutions to real life problems.

Excursions are an important part of every school class. Not infrequently, a teacher would like to take her students to places where a bus trip is not an option.
Virtual field trips are a technological solution. Students can view museum artifacts from the classroom, visit an aquarium, or admire works of art.
Sharing a virtual excursion is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
Because students are often a very critical audience, the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces students to learn more about the world around them." The need to capture the interest of the audience inspires students to write intelligently and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires collaboration and encourages students to continue learning outside of the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; by reacting to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of other texts and express their own perspectives on certain topics. (Oravec, 2002)
Ottawa is Canada's enchanting, bilingual capital, and it features a series of art galleries and museums that present Canada's past and present.
Further south are the Niagara Falls, and to the north the unspoilt beauty of nature in Muskoka and beyond.

Madagascar is by far the largest and, in terms of wildlife, a separate continent.

The Arabs also brought Islam to the country, and on the Comoros and Mayotte it was very successful.
European influence and colonialism began in the 15th century when the Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama discovered the Cape route from Europe to India.
The region is bounded to the north by the Sahel zone and to the south and west by the Atlantic Ocean.

The present-day Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BC and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans and the Merinids as a strategic port under the name Anfa.
The Portuguese destroyed them and rebuilt them under the name Casa Branca, only to abandon them after an earthquake in 1755.
The Moroccan Sultan rebuilt the city as Dar el Beida and it was named Casablanca by Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the most uninteresting places to shop in all of Morocco.

Around the old Medina it is easy to find places where traditional Moroccan wares such as tagines, ceramics, leather goods, water pipes and a whole range of tinnefs are sold, but this is only for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town of the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the extreme east near Rwanda.
In 2002, Goma was destroyed by the lava of the Nyiragongo volcano, which buried most of the city's streets, especially the city centre.
While Goma is relatively safe, every stay outside of Goma should be carefully planned to learn about the ongoing fighting in the province of North Kivu.
The city is also the starting point for the ascent of the volcano Nyiragongo and for some of the cheapest gorilla tracking tours in Africa.
You can use bodabodas (motorcycle taxis) to get around Goma. The usual (local) fare is about 500 Congolese francs for the short trip.
This, combined with its relative inaccessibility, has made "Timbuktu" a metaphor for exotic, far-off countries.

It was one of the most important stops on Louis Gates' PBS special "Wonders of the African World."
The city stands in stark contrast to the rest of the country, as it has more of an Arabic than an African feel.
The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa. It borders Mozambique to the east, Zimbabwe to the north and the Crocodile River to the south.
The park has an area of 19,500 km2 and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each of which supports a different animal population.
It is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily entrance and conservation fees.
It may also be worthwhile to purchase a Wild Card which grants access either to selected parks in South Africa or to all South African national parks.
Hong Kong Island is the namesake of the territory of Hong Kong and is the center of attraction for many tourists.
The buildings that make up the Hong Kong skyline were compared to a shimmering balcony diagram, which is visible due to the presence of the waters of Victoria Harbour.
For the best views of Hong Kong, you should leave the island and take the ferry to the opposite shore of Kowloon.
Most of the urbanization of Hong Kong Island is densely packed along the northern coastline.
This is the place that the British colonists claimed for themselves. If you are looking for traces of the colonial past of the area, this is a good starting point.
The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and extend 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within Indian territory is known as the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans have been a nature reserve since 1966, and according to estimates there are now around 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer there.
Buses run all day long from the inter-district bus station (on the other side of the river), with most buses, especially those heading east and to Jakar/Bumthang, leaving between 06:30 and 07:30.
Because the buses between the districts are often full, it's a good idea to buy a ticket a few days in advance.
Most of the districts are serviced by small Japanese buses, which are comfortable and stable.

The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 metres high, their length is 378 metres and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 metres.
The clearance under the bridge is 15 metres. The construction work was completed in August 2011, but the road was not opened until March 2017.
The bridge is expected to be fully operational in September 2017. It is hoped that the Brazilian customs posts will then be completed.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group inhabiting the eastern Paraguay. They lived as semi-nomadic hunter-gatherers who also practised subsistence agriculture.
The Chaco region was also the home of other groups of indigenous tribes, such as the Guaycurú and the Payaguá, who survived by hunting, gathering and fishing.
Paraguay, formerly known as the Great Province of the West Indies, was created in the 16th century as a result of the meeting of Spanish conquerors and indigenous groups.
The Spaniards began the colonisation period, which lasted three centuries.
Since the founding of Asuncion in 1537, Paraguay has been able to preserve much of its indigenous character and identity.
Argentina is known for having the best polo team and players in the world.

Smaller tournaments and competitions can be viewed at other times of the year as well.
Information on polo tournaments and ticket sales can be found at the Asociación Argentina de Polo.
The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), which is pegged to the value of the British Pound (GBP).
Money can be exchanged at the only bank on the island, which is located across from the FIC West Store in Stanley.
The British pound is generally accepted everywhere on the islands and at Stanley Credit Cards. U.S. dollars are often accepted.
Credit cards are unlikely to be accepted on the remote islands, but British and American currency may be accepted; inquire in advance with the owners as to what payment methods are accepted.
It is almost impossible to exchange the currency of the Falkland Islands outside of the islands themselves, so you should exchange your money before leaving the islands.
Because Montevideo is south of the equator, it is summer there when it is winter in the northern hemisphere and vice versa.

Winter can be deceptively cool: The temperatures rarely go below freezing, but wind and humidity can make it feel colder than the thermometer indicates.
There are no distinct rainy or dry seasons: The rainfall remains more or less constant throughout the year.
